choices.B: Transfer the daily backup files to an EBS volume in AWS and take daily snapshots of the volume
choices.C: Transfer the daily backup files to S3 and use appropriate bucket lifecycle policies to send to Glacier
choices.D: Host the backup files on a Storage Gateway with Gateway-Cached Volumes and take daily snapshots
choices.A: Send the daily backup files to Glacier immediately after being generated

discussion.content:
C all day long. 
Seems more like a SAA question or a CCP but who cares, lol.

Correct Answer: C
data must be held indefinitely + most cost-effective => bucket lifecycle policies to send to Glacier

A - not possible to send files directly to Glacier
B - not cost effective to store in EBS
C - best answer, s3 and using lifecycle policies to move objects to Glacier
D - not cost effective, storage gateway + s3 is not cost effective for long term backup

Full Options D. Ensure all users have been assigned and are frequently rotating a password, access ID/secret key, and 509 certificate

Answer: B C
Doesn't the answer's explanation point to Option D? Could anyone please confirm this question's answer?

comments.content: Correct answer is C - Store in S3 for seven days and then archive to Glacier

discussion.content: C. Transfer the daily backup files to S3 and use appropriate bucket lifecycle policies to send to Glacier
Option D is similar. But snapshot option is not the cost one and limited per region. A & B. Not relevant. so obviously C

comments.content: Ans C : Typo in the above update. Option D is similar. But snapshot option is the cost factor and also limited per region.

questions.answer_description: Because in the stored volume mode, you are storing data locally, the binary-compressed format is already available, and the bandwidth of your AWS connection meets the 7days/2hour SLA.
questions.question_text:
You have a proprietary data store on-premises that must be backed up daily by dumping the data store contents to a single compressed 50GB file and sending the file to AWS. Your SLAs state that any dump file backed up within the past 7 days can be retrieved within 2 hours. Your compliance department has stated that all data must be held indefinitely. The time required to restore the data store from a backup is approximately 1 hour. Your on-premise network connection is capable of sustaining 1gbps to AWS.
Which backup methods to AWS would be most cost-effective while still meeting all of your requirements?

choices.D: The amount of time a Read Replica DB Instance lags behind the source DB Instance
choices.A: The number of outstanding IOs waiting to access the disk.
choices.C: The amount of disk space occupied by binary logs on the master.
choices.E: The average number of disk I/O operations per second.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BDE
I think BDE is correct

Selected Answer: BDE
the three CloudWatch RDS metrics that will help identify if the database is the bottleneck are B. The amount of write latency, D. The amount of time a Read Replica DB Instance lags behind the source DB Instance, and E. The average number of disk I/O operations per second.

Selected Answer: ABE
"The average would not help in bottleneck.
The other factors clearly indicate the bottlenecks, the lags and outstanding requests."
Correct Answers: A, B & E

I think ABD according to https://jayendrapatil.com/aws-rds-monitoring-notification/
"The average would not help in bottleneck.
The other factors clearly indicate the bottlenecks, the lags and outstanding requests."
A,B,E are correct ans

A. The number of outstanding IOs waiting to access the disk.
B. The amount of write latency.
E. The average number of disk I/O operations per second.
i've elected on ADE, seems all agreed on E here...

D might cause end the user to get stale data but not increase in average response time 
so ABE is correct
why Not E?..any comments ?

questions.question_text:
You run a web application with the following components Elastic Load Balancer (EL8), 3 Web/Application servers, 1 MySQL RDS database with read replicas, and
Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) for static content. Average response time for users is increasing slowly.
What three CloudWatch RDS metrics will allow you to identify if the database is the bottleneck? (Choose three.)

choices.A: Create a bucket policy and apply it to the bucket
choices.C: Create an ACL and apply it to all objects in the bucket
choices.B: Create a NACL and attach it to the VPC of the bucket
choices.D: Modify the IAM policies of any users that would access the bucket

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A - https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/block-s3-traffic-vpc-ip/

Bucket policies with "NotIPAddress" can assist with this
Correct Answer: A
A. Create a bucket policy and apply it to the bucket

questions.question_text: Which method can be used to prevent an IP address block from accessing public objects in an S3 bucket?

Your organization is preparing for a security assessment of your use of AWS.
In preparation for this assessment, which two IAM best practices should you consider implementing? (Choose two.)

choices.C: Assign IAM users and groups configured with policies granting least privilege access
choices.B: Configure MFA on the root account and for privileged IAM users
choices.D: Ensure all users have been assigned and are frequently rotating a password, access ID/secret key, and X.509 certificate
choices.A: Create individual IAM users for everyone in your organization

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
A. Creating individual IAM users for everyone in your organization is a good practice for user management, but it does not directly address security concerns or IAM best practices.

Selected Answer: BC
B & C - https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/best-practices.html
Correct Answers: B & C
Not sure why D is ignored, Ensuring rotation of credentials is definitely a good practice.

comments.content: I dismissed D as an option because of the last part:" access ID/secret key, and....."

discussion.content:
B. Configure MFA on the root account and for privileged IAM users
C. Assign IAM users and groups configured with policies granting least privilege access

comments.content: Reanalyzed again. Looks default answers are good.

discussion.content: Assuming why not A considered. Scenario : if LDAP or AD is used in organization then, creating individual user is not required.

choices.D: Run the RDS instance on the largest size possible
choices.B: Use ElastiCache to offload the analytics job data
choices.C: Create RDS Read-Replicas for the analytics work
choices.A: Enable Multi-AZ mode on the RDS instance

questions.question_text:
Your business is building a new application that will store its entire customer database on a RDS MySQL database, and will have various applications and users that will query that data for different purposes.
Large analytics jobs on the database are likely to cause other applications to not be able to get the query results they need to, before time out. Also, as your data grows, these analytics jobs will start to take more time, increasing the negative effect on the other applications.
How do you solve the contention issues between these different workloads on the same data?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
B, is another option, but C seems more practical (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/24728634/aws-elasticache-vs-rds-readreplica)
C all day long.
Correct Answer: C
C. Create RDS Read-Replicas for the analytics work
